sub_strands.name: Elements and Compounds
descriptions: Atoms, elements, molecules and compounds
Symbols of common elements (oxygen, carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, iron, aluminium, copper, silver, gold, chlorine, sodium, mercury, lead)
Word equations for reactions of elements to form compounds (sodium chloride, water, carbon dioxide, copper oxide, aluminium oxide)
Uses of some common elements in the society (jewellery, construction, electricity, food nutrients, mineral elements, medals)
learning_outcomes: Explain the relationship between an atom, an element, a molecule and a compound
Assign symbols to selected elements
Write word equations to represent reactions of selected elements to form compounds
Outline the applications of common elements in the society
Appreciate the information on packaging labels of commonly consumed substances
learning_experiences: Discuss the meaning of atoms, elements, molecules and compounds
Collaboratively sample labelled containers of different substances, identify and record the elements or compounds on the containers
Collaboratively represent selected elements using symbols
Use word equations to represent reactions of elements to form compounds
Identify elements in selected compounds (compounds with only two elements)
Explore the importance and value of common elements and compounds in day-to-day life
Use digital or print media to search for information on atoms, elements, molecules and compounds or observe simulations
key_inquiries: Why is it important to use symbols for representing elements in day-to-day life?
core_competencies: Learning to learn: The learner reflects on their own experiences as they identify elements and compounds on labels of containers
Communication and collaboration: The learner writes clearly the symbols of elements, compounds, word equations
values: Unity: The learner cooperates and harmoniously works with others while identifying elements and compounds from sample labelled containers of different substances
pertinent_issues: Financial literacy: The learner explores the value of common elements and compounds in society as they learn about their importance and value in day-to-day life
other_learning_areas: Linked to Agriculture: The learner relates the use of ingredients and items made from common elements and compounds
non_formal_activities: Interviews with professionals on element/compound usage

skills.skill: Ability to differentiate between elements and compounds

rubrics.Exceeds: Clearly and consistently differentiates between elements and compounds with examples
rubrics.Meets: Correctly differentiates between elements and compounds
rubrics.Approaches: Partially differentiates between elements and compounds

sub_strands.name: Physical and Chemical Changes
descriptions: Characteristics of physical and chemical changes
Differences between physical and chemical changes
Examples of physical and chemical changes
Importance of physical and chemical changes in day-to-day life
learning_outcomes: Describe characteristics of physical and chemical changes
Differentiate between physical and chemical changes
Classify changes as either physical or chemical
Relate physical and chemical changes to day-to-day life
Appreciate the relevance of physical and chemical changes in day-to-day life
learning_experiences: Carry out simple experiments to demonstrate physical changes (melting of ice, cutting of paper, dissolving sugar in water, heating of wax)
Carry out simple experiments to demonstrate chemical changes (burning paper, rusting, cooking an egg, mixing acid and base, fermentation of milk)
Use print and digital media to search for more information and simulations on physical and chemical changes
Classify changes observed in various situations as physical or chemical
Relate observed changes to day-to-day life
key_inquiries: How are physical and chemical changes different?
Why are they important in day-to-day life?
core_competencies: Learning to learn: The learner applies learnt knowledge to identify and classify observed changes as physical or chemical
Communication and collaboration: The learner works in teams to carry out experiments and share findings on physical and chemical changes
values: Integrity: The learner displays honesty in recording observed results from physical and chemical change experiments
Responsibility: The learner safely handles materials and manages waste during experiments
pertinent_issues: Environmental safety: The learner observes safety procedures while handling chemicals and disposing of waste from experiments
other_learning_areas: Linked to Pre-technical Studies: Relating heat and chemical processes in cooking and metal works
non_formal_activities: Demonstrations by science club members on physical and chemical changes

skills.skill: Ability to distinguish between physical and chemical changes

rubrics.Exceeds: Clearly distinguishes between physical and chemical changes and provides real-life examples
rubrics.Meets: Correctly distinguishes physical from chemical changes

sub_strands.name: Classes of Fire
descriptions: Types and classes of fire (Class A - ordinary combustibles, Class B - flammable liquids, Class C - electrical fires, Class D - combustible metals, Class K - cooking oils and fats)
Fire extinguishers used to control different classes of fire
Fire safety measures at home, school and workplace
learning_outcomes: Identify the different classes of fire
Match each class of fire with the appropriate fire extinguisher
Describe appropriate fire safety measures at home, school and workplace
Appreciate the importance of fire safety and preparedness
learning_experiences: Observe and classify different types of fire using videos or safe simulations
Match various classes of fire with suitable types of fire extinguishers
Simulate fire response drills in school
Visit a fire station or explore a virtual tour of firefighting facilities
Create and present posters or campaigns on fire safety and prevention
key_inquiries: What are the different classes of fire?
Which extinguisher is used for each class of fire?
How can fire disasters be prevented or managed?
core_competencies: Citizenship: The learner demonstrates civic responsibility in fire preparedness
Self-efficacy: The learner shows initiative in participating in fire safety simulations
values: Responsibility: The learner takes precautionary measures seriously when simulating fire drills
Courage: The learner confidently participates in discussions and activities about fire response
pertinent_issues: Safety and disaster preparedness: The learner prepares for emergencies by understanding fire types and appropriate responses
other_learning_areas: Linked to Social Studies and Life Skills: The learner relates disaster response and safety education
learning_materials: Samples or replicas of fire extinguishers
Videos or animations of fire response scenarios
Charts showing fire classes and extinguishers
non_formal_activities: Organizing a school fire safety campaign or poster competition
Inviting resource persons from fire departments to give talks

skills.skill: Ability to identify fire classes and use appropriate extinguishing methods

rubrics.Exceeds: Identifies all fire classes and confidently matches them with the correct extinguishers and safety actions
rubrics.Meets: Identifies most fire classes with correct extinguishers and provides suitable responses
rubrics.Approaches: Identifies some fire classes and matches some extinguishers with guidance
rubrics.Below: Identifies fire classes and extinguishers with prompts and limited accuracy

sub_strands.name: The Cell
descriptions: Structure of plant and animal cells (cell wall, cell membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus, chloroplasts, vacuole)
Functions of parts of plant and animal cells
Similarities and differences between plant and animal cells
learning_outcomes: Describe the structure and functions of parts of plant and animal cells
Differentiate between plant and animal cells
Appreciate the role of cells in living organisms
learning_experiences: Use microscopes to observe prepared slides of plant and animal cells
Label diagrams of plant and animal cells
Construct models of plant and animal cells using locally available materials
Discuss similarities and differences between plant and animal cells in groups
Use digital or print media to search for more information on cell structure and functions
key_inquiries: What are the parts and functions of plant and animal cells?
How are plant and animal cells similar or different?
core_competencies: Critical thinking and problem solving: The learner interprets observed features of cells from microscope slides and models
Learning to learn: The learner reflects on the functions of each cell part and how they relate to life processes
values: Responsibility: The learner handles equipment like microscopes with care during observations
Respect: The learner values peers’ contributions during group discussions on cell functions
pertinent_issues: Environmental awareness: The learner relates healthy cell function to overall health of living things
other_learning_areas: Linked to Agriculture and Nutrition: Relating cell functions to plant and animal growth
non_formal_activities: School science club exhibitions or competitions on cell models

skills.skill: Ability to identify and describe parts of plant and animal cells

rubrics.Exceeds: Clearly identifies and describes parts of plant and animal cells using accurate scientific vocabulary
rubrics.Meets: Identifies and describes most parts of plant and animal cells correctly
rubrics.Approaches: Identifies some parts of cells with partial descriptions
rubrics.Below: Identifies parts with prompts and incomplete descriptions

sub_strands.name: Movement of Materials In and Out of the Cell
descriptions: Processes of diffusion and osmosis
Demonstration of diffusion and osmosis using simple experiments
Importance of diffusion and osmosis in living organisms
learning_outcomes: Describe the processes of diffusion and osmosis
Demonstrate diffusion and osmosis using simple experiments
Relate diffusion and osmosis to movement of materials in living organisms
Appreciate the importance of diffusion and osmosis in living organisms
learning_experiences: Perform simple experiments to demonstrate diffusion and osmosis (e.g. food colouring in water, peeled potatoes in salt/sugar solution)
Observe and describe movement of materials during experiments
Use print and digital media to search for more information or watch simulations of diffusion and osmosis
Discuss the role of diffusion and osmosis in absorption and excretion in plants and animals
key_inquiries: Why are these processes important in living organisms?
core_competencies: Communication and collaboration: The learner works effectively with peers while performing and recording results from experiments
Self-efficacy: The learner confidently sets up and interprets outcomes of osmosis and diffusion experiments
values: Integrity: The learner records experimental results honestly and objectively
Responsibility: The learner carefully handles experiment materials and ensures safety during investigations
pertinent_issues: Health and nutrition: The learner relates osmosis to absorption of nutrients and water in body systems
other_learning_areas: Linked to Home Science and Nutrition: Exploring nutrient absorption and food preservation
non_formal_activities: Science project: Observe and document osmosis in various plant tissues or food items

skills.skill: Ability to demonstrate and explain diffusion and osmosis

rubrics.Exceeds: Clearly demonstrates and explains diffusion and osmosis using accurate scientific terms and real-life examples
rubrics.Meets: Demonstrates and explains diffusion and osmosis with appropriate examples
rubrics.Approaches: Demonstrates the processes with some explanation
rubrics.Below: Attempts demonstration with minimal or unclear explanation

sub_strands.name: Reproduction in Human Beings
descriptions: Parts of the male and female reproductive systems and their functions
Fertilisation and development of the embryo
Hygiene and care during puberty
Importance of responsible sexual behaviour
learning_outcomes: Describe the parts and functions of the human reproductive system
Explain the process of fertilisation and development of the embryo
Practise appropriate hygiene and care during puberty
Demonstrate responsible behaviour regarding sexuality
Appreciate the importance of reproductive health and responsibility
learning_experiences: Use charts, models or digital media to identify parts of the male and female reproductive systems and describe their functions
Watch animations or simulations on fertilisation and development of the embryo
Role-play personal hygiene practices during puberty and discuss importance of each
Hold discussions with resource persons or health experts on responsible sexual behaviour
Use digital or print media to explore changes during puberty and coping strategies
key_inquiries: What are the parts and functions of the male and female reproductive systems?
What changes occur during puberty and how can they be managed responsibly?
Why is responsible sexual behaviour important?
core_competencies: Self-efficacy: The learner manages changes during puberty through responsible choices and personal care
Learning to learn: The learner reflects on physical, emotional, and social changes during adolescence
values: Integrity: The learner demonstrates self-respect and honesty when discussing matters of sexuality and puberty
Respect: The learner appreciates differences in individual development during adolescence
pertinent_issues: Sexual and reproductive health education: The learner explores healthy behaviours and responsible decision-making during adolescence
other_learning_areas: Linked to Life Skills and Home Science: Promoting hygiene, values, and communication on sexual health
non_formal_activities: Inviting health experts, peer mentors or counsellors for discussions on reproductive health and puberty

skills.skill: Ability to describe parts of the reproductive system and their functions

rubrics.Exceeds: Describes parts and functions of the reproductive system clearly, using accurate vocabulary and examples
rubrics.Meets: Describes most parts and functions of the reproductive system accurately
rubrics.Approaches: Describes some parts and functions with basic understanding
rubrics.Below: Describes few parts with prompts and limited accuracy

sub_strands.name: Transformation of Energy
descriptions: Forms of energy (heat, light, sound, electrical, chemical, mechanical)
Transformation of one form of energy to another (e.g., solar to electrical, chemical to mechanical, electrical to heat)
Applications of energy transformation in day-to-day life
learning_outcomes: Identify various forms of energy
Describe how one form of energy can be transformed into another
Relate transformation of energy to real-life situations
Appreciate the importance of energy transformation in day-to-day life
learning_experiences: Observe and identify different forms of energy (e.g., heat from a fire, light from a bulb, sound from a drum)
Conduct simple experiments to show transformation of energy (e.g., battery lighting a bulb, solar panel powering a device, dynamo generating electricity)
Explore devices such as solar panels, generators, electric motors and relate to the type of energy transformation involved
Use digital or print media to search for simulations or real-life examples of energy transformation
Discuss in groups the role of energy transformation in tools and appliances used at home or school
key_inquiries: What are the different forms of energy?
How is energy transformed from one form to another?
How is this transformation useful in daily life?
core_competencies: Learning to learn: The learner relates experiences with various energy forms to new concepts during experiments and simulations
Critical thinking and problem solving: The learner analyses how devices work based on energy transformation principles
values: Responsibility: The learner carefully handles materials during energy transformation experiments
Innovation: The learner applies knowledge of energy transformation to suggest or create basic energy-efficient tools
pertinent_issues: Environmental sustainability: The learner explores clean energy sources such as solar and wind, and their role in conserving the environment
other_learning_areas: Linked to Pre-technical and Business Studies: Using energy transformation concepts in design and technology
non_formal_activities: Science project: Build a simple device demonstrating energy transformation (e.g., solar-powered fan or dynamo light)

skills.skill: Ability to describe transformation of energy and its application

rubrics.Exceeds: Clearly describes multiple energy transformations and relates them to real-world tools and devices
rubrics.Meets: Describes energy transformation and gives appropriate real-life examples
rubrics.Approaches: Describes some energy transformations with limited examples
rubrics.Below: Describes few or no transformations with assistance

sub_strands.name: Pressure
descriptions: Concept of pressure in solids, liquids and gases
Factors affecting pressure (force and area)
Measurement of pressure
Applications of pressure in day-to-day life (e.g., syringe, hydraulic brake, straw, suction pump, bicycle pump)
learning_outcomes: Define pressure and explain how it acts in solids, liquids and gases
Identify factors that affect pressure
Describe how pressure is measured
Relate pressure to day-to-day applications
Appreciate the usefulness of pressure in real-life situations
learning_experiences: Perform simple experiments using syringes, balloons, beakers and weights to demonstrate pressure in solids, liquids and gases
Measure pressure using force and area relationships
Explore the use of pressure in devices such as suction pumps, hydraulic lifts, and brake systems
Use digital or print media to search for information and simulations on applications of pressure
Discuss applications of pressure at home, in transport and in industrial machines
key_inquiries: How does pressure behave in solids, liquids and gases?
How is pressure used in real-life situations?
core_competencies: Communication and collaboration: The learner exchanges ideas while conducting pressure-related experiments and sharing results
Self-efficacy: The learner sets up and interprets outcomes of pressure experiments with confidence
values: Respect: The learner listens and responds constructively to peers’ views during investigations
Responsibility: The learner takes care of tools and ensures safety while handling materials during experiments
pertinent_issues: Sustainable engineering: The learner explores use of pressure in tools that improve efficiency in farming, health, and transport
other_learning_areas: Linked to Mathematics: Calculating pressure using formulas involving force and area
Linked to Pre-technical Studies: Exploring pressure in machines and simple systems
non_formal_activities: Visit to a local garage, hospital or workshop to observe applications of hydraulic or pneumatic systems
Invite guest speaker to demonstrate devices using pressure

skills.skill: Ability to explain pressure and its application in real life

rubrics.Exceeds: Explains pressure clearly and links it to accurate and diverse real-life applications
rubrics.Meets: Explains pressure and identifies relevant real-life applications
rubrics.Approaches: Explains pressure with some clarity and limited examples
rubrics.Below: Struggles to explain pressure or provide real-life examples
